description: From Middle English desert, deseert, from Old French deserte, from deservir (“to deserve”), from Vulgar Latin dēserviō (“to gain or merit by giving service”).

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) That which is deserved or merited; a just punishment or reward.
examples: From the highest spire of contentment / my fortune is thrown; / and fear and grief and pain for my deserts / are my hopes, since hope is gone.

description: From Middle English desert (“wilderness”), from Old French desert, from Latin dēsertum, past participle of dēserō (“to abandon”). Generally displaced native Old English wēsten.

entries.meaning: Usually of a place: abandoned, deserted, or uninhabited.
examples: They were marooned on a desert island in the Pacific.

entries.meaning: A barren area of land or desolate terrain, especially one with little water or vegetation; a wasteland.

examples: He declared that the country was an intellectual desert; that he was famishing for spiritual aliment, and for discourse on matters beyond mere nuggets, prospectings, and the price of gold.

description: Borrowed from French déserter, from Late Latin desertō, from Latin desertus, from deserō (“abandon”).

verbs.description: desert (third-person singular simple present deserts, present participle deserting, simple past and past participle deserted)

entries.meaning: To leave (anything that depends on one's presence to survive, exist, or succeed), especially when contrary to a promise or obligation; to abandon; to forsake.
examples: You can't just drive off and desert me here, in the middle of nowhere.

entries.meaning: To leave one's duty or post, especially to leave a military or naval unit without permission.
examples: Anyone found deserting will be punished.
